intro: Pachystela cinerea var. undulata, commonly known as the undulating ghost orchid, is a rare and striking member of the Orchidaceae family. It is characterized by its pale, ghostly white flowers with undulating, wavy petals that give it its common name. This plant is epiphytic, meaning it grows on the surface of trees or other plants without deriving nutrients from them. It thrives in humid, shaded environments, typically in tropical and subtropical regions. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is often found in protected areas and is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
